value.job_description: **SELECTIVE CERTIFICATION: CHINESE/MANDARIN      The mission of the Bureau of Immunization (BOI) is to improve the health of all New Yorkers through prevention and control of vaccine preventable diseases including hepatitis B.  The Perinatal Hepatitis B Prevention Unit is responsible for conducting surveillance for hepatitis B infected pregnant women, and providing case management to help prevent the transmission of hepatitis B from the infected mothers to their newborns and contacts. The Public Health Advisor I (PHA I) works under the supervision of a Supervising Public Health Advisor in the Perinatal Hepatitis B Prevention (PHBP) Unit in the Bureau of Immunization.     Duties include:     Conduct case investigations and case management of hepatitis B positive pregnant women/mothers, their newborns and their household contacts (citywide).   Provide education about hepatitis B disease and prevention methods for hepatitis B infected pregnant women and new mothers in person or over the phone.   Conduct patient interviews to collect data on demographics, medical information and risk factors. Remind and assist mothers with scheduling medical appointments for vaccinating and testing their newborns for hepatitis B.   Obtain vaccination and laboratory records from healthcare and laboratory facilities.   Monitor compliance with recommended vaccine schedule for infants and household contacts using a computerized data management system.

The core values of the OCME are to put the mission of the agency first, to be truly dedicated and to have integrity in every aspect of our professional life. Under direction, with latitude for the exercise of independent initiative and judgment, investigates cases of sudden, unexpected, suspicious and violent deaths. value.job_description: Under the direction of the Director of Neighborhood Preservation Strategies, the Community Partners will develop, implement, and manage Community Partnership and Housing Preservation activities.  The Community Partners are responsible for liaising with the community to develop integrated, informed preservation solutions for community residents and owners.    The goal of the Community Partnerships division is to act as a bridge between divisions within HPD and also private and public community partners to further the preservation of affordable housing in New York City. A core objective is to assist in the preservation of affordable housing within our neighborhoods through engaging landlords with our preservation financing tools, and working towards stopping displacement of tenants from homes they can afford.     All Community Partners in the unit are expected to perform similar duties and responsibilities to ensure a flexible and multi-disciplined team.  Selected duties for the Community Partnership team include liaising with and creating partnerships with community groups where HPD and community interests align; creating and presenting formal and informal presentations to elected officials, community groups and community residents; researching regulatory and other housing related law; and analyzing landlord and building financial portfolios. All Community Partners within the Community Partnerships division are expected to participate and assist in neighborhood workshops, as necessary.

value.job_description: The New York City Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) protects public health and the environment by supplying clean drinking water, collecting and treating wastewater, and reducing air, noise, and hazardous materials pollution.  DEP is the largest combined municipal water and wastewater utility in the country, with nearly 6,000 employees.  We deliver 1.1 billion gallons of high quality drinking water per day to 8.3 million New York City residents and more than 1 million people in Upstate New York, and we collect and treat an average of 1.3 billion gallons of wastewater per day. The goal of this division is for all employees to be proficient in all environmental, health and safety practices and regulations which pertain to their work assignments, that the facilities operated by the bureau will be remediated and maintained in a manner which is safe, compliant and efficient, and that self-perpetuating human resource policies and practices will be implanted in all operations. value.job_description: The Division of Sandy Recovery seeks a Project Manager for the Multifamily Storm Recovery Program, which provides loans and grants to assist multifamily developments that were impacted by Hurricane Sandy.   In NYC, it is estimated that more than 60,000 residential units were damaged by Hurricane Sandy.  New York City's Build it Back Program provides reconstruction, rehabilitation, and reimbursement assistance to all Build it Back-registered residential buildings impacted by Hurricane Sandy, from single family homes to high-density multifamily housing, as well as rental assistance to displaced low-income tenants. Projects range in size from individual condo/coop units to developments with 5 to 1,500 or more units.    HPD has also partnered with three Community Development Finance Institutions (CDFIs) as sub-grantees/recipients to provide funds to the affected buildings: the Community Preservation Corporation (CPC), the Local Initiatives Support Corporation (LISC) and the New York City Housing Development Corporation (NYC HDC). value.business_title: ANCP Project Manager / Junior Underwriter / Analyst
value.job_description: The Division of Property Disposition and Finance seeks a Project Manager/Junior Underwriter/Analyst for the Affordable Neighborhood Cooperative Program (ANCP).  The Division of Property Disposition and Finance administers multiple loan programs: ANCP, Multi-family Preservation Loan Program, Third Party Transfer, and several small home repair and loan programs - which facilitate the rehabilitation of public and privately-owned multifamily buildings throughout New York City.  ANCP provides low-interest loans for the rehabilitation of occupied City-owned buildings.  After rehabilitation the buildings become affordable cooperatives for low and moderate income households. HPD provides subsidy through City Capital in addition to construction and permanent financing sources provided by, but not limited to: private institutional lenders, State of New York Mortgage Agency (SONYMA) and New York State Affordable Housing Corporation (AHC) programs.  At construction loan closing, HPD conveys properties to Restoring Communities HDFC (â€œRCâ€), a subsidiary of Neighborhood Restore.   RC will pass day-to-day operating authority for the rehabilitation of the project to a private developer, either for-profit or not-for-profit, selected through a Requests for Qualifications.  The developer is responsible for obtaining financing, temporarily relocating tenants, completing substantial rehabilitation of the property, and converting it to cooperative ownership. Following completion of rehabilitation, RC conveys the building to a cooperative housing corporation formed by the buildingâ€™s tenants.  Returning tenants purchase the cooperative interests attributable to their apartments for $2,500 per dwelling unit, while vacant units are sold for market prices to households with incomes not exceeding 120% AMI.  Under the direction of the ANCP Director and Senior Project Manager, the Project Manager/ Junior Underwriter/Analyst will be responsible for financial underwriting and project management for an assigned group of ANCP projects, including the loan commitment, loan closing, and construction phases.  There will be significant contact with developers, tenants and affordable housing lenders and an opportunity to work on a multiple loan projects and to assist with modeling and developing new financial structures.    Primary responsibilities will include, but not be limited to:  Determining feasibility of proposed projects and proposed loan terms, including performing financial analysis; Modeling, preparing, reviewing, interpreting, and making recommendations related to development budgets, pro formas, and affordability analyses; Preparing credit committee and other project proposal materials for senior staff review; Acting as a liaison to developers, financial institutions and other project partners, other HPD divisions, and governmental agencies to resolve problems and move projects forward; Tracking, monitoring and troubleshooting projects through processing, commitment, pre-construction, and construction;  Attending tenant and community meetings to represent the agency, explain the program, and specific project details;   Counseling designated developers in program policies, regulations, and assisting to resolve issues related to their projects.

value.job_description: The Tax Incentive Programs unit administers a wide variety of tax abatement and exemption programs to facilitate private and publicly-subsidized rehabilitation and new construction programs throughout New York City.    420-c/Article XI Analyst  The 420-c and Article XI tax exemption programs are administered by HPD to help facilitate the construction and rehabilitation of affordable housing in New York City.  The 420-c program provides a full or partial exemption from real estate taxes to affordable housing that has been developed with low-income housing tax credits.  The Article XI program provides, upon the approval of both HPD and the City Council, a full or partial exemption to affordable housing owned by Housing Development Fund Companies.     Under the supervision of the Tax Incentive Programs Director and/or Deputy Director, the 420-c/Article XI Analyst will perform complex technical, administrative and analytical work in managing the programs.  Responsibilities include, but are not limited to:    Review and verify completeness of exemption applications and the accuracy of certificates for compliance with applicable program law, policy, procedures and rules;    Coordinating review with the development team, finance sources, and agency loan staff and providing research support, training, supervision, and troubleshooting for Division and agency staff to resolve program issues;    Draft submissions for City Council approval of Article XI tax exemptions;    Review and analyze project-specific underwriting analyses for the Article XI and 420-c programs;    With the assistance of the TIP Director and Deputy Director, interpret applicable laws and regulations for tax programs;     Provide technical assistance in the interpretation of program requirements to the agency staff and the public;     Create and maintain program indicators, statistics, and program revenue collections; and     Perform analytical and other special projects identified by the unit director.

value.job_description: The Corporate Alliance Program (CAP)   The Corporate Alliance Program (CAP) is collaboration between the NYC Department of Small Business Services and nine major corporations and one university who work to connect city-certified M/WBEs and small businesses to their vendor opportunities.  CAP has three major initiatives, including:    â€¢M/WBE Recruitment Service - SBS extends its targeted matching services to CAP partners to provide access to the cityâ€™s extensive M/WBE database for contract opportunities.  Additionally, we work with partners to assist with certifying any of their non-certified M/WBE vendors and to enroll qualified City-certified M/WBEs into their supplier databases.    â€¢CAP/NYCEO Mentorship â€“ SBS, in partnership with Entrepreneursâ€™ Organization, offers this cohort-based mentorship program that pairs small businesses with successful entrepreneurs who will serve as their mentors, and corporate executives to provide specific business area guidance and learning sessions, in order to help develop participantsâ€™ overall capacity and focus on their ability to bid and perform on large corporate contract opportunities.    â€¢Navigating the Corporate Supply Chain Workshop Series (NCSC) â€“ SBS and its corporate partners educate and train small businesses on how to do business with large corporations through monthly workshops. value.job_description: The Office of Policy, Planning and Strategic Data Use (PPSDU) in the Division of the First Deputy Commissioner for the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH) is seeking a Director of Policy and Health Systems Analysis. The Director will report to the Executive Director of PPSDU and is considered a critical management position for DOHMH.     PPSDUâ€™s scope includes creation of a DOHMH agenda addressing health promotion, health equity, and health-in-all policies; increasing DOHMH capacity for collaboration with the health care system; and promoting evidence-based and data-driven population health programming in the health care system     The Director of Policy and Health Systems Analysis will support this work by 1) monitoring and reporting on health reforms (including DSRIP, SHIP, ACA) and their impact; 2) leading novel analyses that show the population health impact of ongoing reforms; and 3) helping develop policy and programmatic strategies to address emerging problems for population health improvement in NYC.     Core duties:    â€¢	Monitor and serve as a resource to agency leadership and colleagues regarding changes in the federal, state and local health systems/health care environment and opportunities for the agency and its programs to promote population health and health equity in New York City.     â€¢	Provide leadership in the creation of new analyses that can inform the agency, NYC-area stakeholders, and NYS leadership about the impacts of health reform in NYC: formulate strategic research questions; lead staff in conducting analyses of Medicaid data, agency data, and other information; and write reports that will be useful to a range of audiences (including the NYC PHIP Steering Committee)    â€¢	Help advance the agencyâ€™s agenda (including Take Care New York): work with agency leadership to advance the agencyâ€™s policy agenda in relation to public health programming, promoting health-in-all policies, and increasing alignment with the health care community; anticipate and identify issues, legislation, regulations, and rule-making that impact the health of New Yorkers; coordinate efforts to develop and organize responses for City, State, and Federal legislative and regulatory changes;   	  â€¢	Provide technical assistance in planning designing, implementing, and evaluating programmatic and administrative initiatives related to health reform.

value.job_description: DoITT provides for the sustained, efficient and effective delivery of IT services, infrastructure and telecommunications to enhance service delivery to New York City's residents, businesses, employees and visitors. value.job_description: AMENDED PROGRAM DESCRIPTION **    Salary Range:  $ 56,555.00 Hiring Rate (Flat Rate)    On-board After One Year: $62,210.00- $ 68,431.00 (Annual)     The Bureau of Correctional Health Services (CHS) coordinates comprehensive medical, dental, mental health and discharge planning services for inmates in New York City's correctional facilities.  CHS provides health care on a 24 hour a day, 7 days a week basis.  This is accomplished through the direct provision of care and contracted provider services.  There is an extensive monitoring program to ensure that patient needs are met within established health care guidelines.     CHS has a vacancy for a Data Manager/Court Advocate position for the new Program for Accelerating Clinical Effectiveness (PACE) units on Rikers Island. The PACE units leverage key inputs of successful clinically-driven jail housing, which include treatment aids that engage with patients and facilitate their participation in group activities and other treatment efforts; a treatment-focused patient schedule with morning meetings, multiple day and evening programs,  and one-on-one encounters; and frequent, regular meetings between Department of Correction, Corizon and DOHMH staff to ensure collaborative decision making on all issues, from the day-to day operations to long term strategic plans. PACE units will serve as the housing location for patients who have been determined to suffer from acute mental health crises and significant mental illness.  AMENDED **     SPECIFIC DUTIES WILL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:     --  Assisting in establishing and maintaining relationships with jail-based health care and mental health providers, attorneys/defense providers, and specialized courts citywide.    -- Completing program progress reports and providing to the courts as necessary.    -- Collecting relevant patient data, assessing patient eligibility for community based alternatives to detention and advocating for the individual to be considered for this service or specialty court for an expedited release.    -- Entering patient information into program databased in a timely manner.    -- Assist in designing research investigations on programmatic issues, conducting data analyses and preparing reports.     --Preparing reports on research and data management tasks.    --Assisting  in the coordination of research and evaluation efforts in CHS.    -- Coordinate release plan with mental health treatment team and discharge planning; and, Ability to work within a correctional setting environment/inmate housing area.

value.job_description: The Civilian Complaint Review Board (â€œCCRBâ€) is charged with investigating and mediating complaints which members of the public file against New York City police officers involving the use of force, abuse of authority, discourtesy or offensive language. The Board consists of 13 members who are appointed by the Mayor, the City Council and the Police Commissioner and who, along with the Executive Director, govern all operations of the agency. The CCRB is also charged with operating its Administrative Prosecution Unit (â€œAPUâ€) which prosecutes all cases substantiated by the Board. Additional information concerning the CCRB is available at www.nyc.gov/ccrb.  The Strategic Initiative Specialist (SIP) reports directly to the Deputy Executive Director for Policy and  Strategic Initiatives and will be responsible for the following:   The SIP works with executive staff on developing the agencys strategic plan and preparing materials to translate the strategic plan into specific guidelines. The SIP works with executive staff on providing programmatic expertise and analysis so programs and staff allocations correspond with the mission and goals of the agency.  The SIP writes confidential memoranda recommending changes to policies and practices of the Police Department.  The SIP also works with agency executives in the drafting of public testimony, public reports and policy memoranda.   Using quantitative techniques and the CCRB's Complaint Tracking System, the SIP prepares the CCRB's bi-annual report to the Mayor and the City Council, monthly disposition reports on case investigations and prosecutions, monthly reports to the Mayor's Office of Operations, the monthly report of the Executive Director to the Board and internal productivity reports, as requested.   The SIP works with executive staff on providing budget and policy support so budget allocations correspond with the mission and goals of the agency.  The SIP prepares quantitative and qualitative analyses to be used in the agency's budget submissions, including New Needs, PEGs and other memoranda. Also, the SIP participates in meetings with OMB, MMR, and City Council staff to discuss budget and performance related memoranda.

value.job_description: The Field Services Unit in the HIV Epidemiology and Field Services Program (HEFSP) is responsible for providing HIV partner services and linkage to care to HIV-diagnosed persons in New York City (NYC), including the collection, analysis, and dissemination of service data of participating patients. NYC has a large and diverse HIV epidemic, and analyses of partner and linkage to care service data in NYC inform public health policy at the local, state, and national levels.    The Unit is recruiting an experienced epidemiologist to serve as a Program Analyst (City Research Scientist III), reporting to the Director of Field Services Unit. The Program Analyst may be asked to contribute to a wide range of activities, including routine program planning, evaluation and operational research, as well as special investigative studies, and the Medical Monitoring Project (MMP). MMP is a CDC-funded, multi-year enhanced surveillance project with annual, cross-sectional data collection on a sample of HIV-infected adults that is designed to be locally and nationally representative of all adults in medical care for HIV.   Tasks as Program Analyst will include:    â€¢	Examining program functions and procedures to identify strengths and weaknesses and contribute to program retooling.  â€¢	Managing multiple research/evaluation and quality management projects.  â€¢	Carrying out routine functions of data management unit as assigned, such as data monitoring and quality assurance, programmatic reports to grantees, special data requests, program tables, slide sets, assisting in the preparation of analytics datasets, and other routine tasks.   â€¢	Integrating data from different systems as needed to ensure data quality and completeness and to carry out merged analyses.  â€¢	Cleaning, managing, analyzing and displaying data using analytic software packages (including SAS).  â€¢	Contributing to data systems specifications, documentation, testing, and user support/technical assistance; and producing tables, indicator results, reports, presentations and papers based on reviewed and original work, for dissemination.  â€¢	Preparing abstracts and articles for presentation and publication.   â€¢	Prepare and deliver oral presentations of epidemiologic analyses to different audiences, including scientific audiences inside and outside the health department, and community groups.

value.preferred_skills: Prior experience managing large databases essential; good analytical skills, including advanced knowledge of SAS and familiarity with ODS; experience with ArcGIS helpful; attention to detail and appreciation for data quality; ability to work with a diverse staff of epidemiologists, analysts, and public health advisors; good written and oral communication skills.  Preferred candidates will have strong analytical, organizational and communication skills; demonstrated ability to manage projects; experience with the testing, documentation, support, or maintenance of health and service-related information systems; solid working knowledge of SAS, as well as MS Office; a firm grasp of infectious disease epidemiology and clinical and supportive service program evaluation; and an appreciation for data quality and program quality management. Measure and track internal performance within each spend category by tracking forecasted vs. actual savings and budget impact for the portfolio of commodities and communicate performance; and managing the development of data dashboards.      Monitor strategy implementation by coordinating and communicating overall sourcing trends/ results of commodities to the CFO and business unit leadership.     Drive annual productivity improvements in each spend category by developing and ensuring the implementation of ideas to optimize total cost of ownership for spend categories within the portfolio. value.job_description: Working within the Environmental, Health and Safety (EHS) Directorate of the Bureau of Water Supply (BWS), the selected candidate will serve as a Site EHS Officer, focusing primarily on facilities and staff located in the Highlands Region.  The Industrial Hygienist will report directly to the EHS Facility Compliance Eastern Division Supervisor and will work closely with the Regional Manager and facility operational staff. Under direction, the Industrial Hygienist will be responsible for ensuring the overall day-to-day EHS compliance of various facilities in the regional area. In addition, the Industrial Hygienist will be responsible for managing and maintaining EHS information, which includes the use of spreadsheets, databases, and record retention systems.  They will provide certain EHS training for staff at assigned facilities, meet with staff to explain the proper selection and use of PPE and other safety tools, coordinate and conduct incident investigations and root cause analyses, and act as a local resource for EHS questions and concerns.    The successful candidate will be knowledgeable of Federal, New York State, and local EHS regulations, laws and requirements, possess excellent communication skills, be thoroughly familiar with Microsoft Word and Excel, and be able to wear/use required personal protective equipment. value.job_description: ** $56,555 - Hiring Rate (Flat - Annual)    On-Board: $62,210 - $ 68,431 (Annual)    The Health Departmentâ€™s Division of Prevention and Primary Care, Bureau of Correctional Health Services (CHS) is responsible for the delivery of all health and mental health services in the NYC jail system. Core CHS activities include formulating and implementing all policies and procedures as well as administering quality assurance, quality improvement, morbidity and mortality reviews as well as coordinating re-entry services. value.job_description: The New York City Law Department is seeking Discovery Management Attorneys in the Litigation Support Division.
